description: From Latin sēparātus, perfect passive participle of sēparāre (“to separate”), from sē (“apart”) +‎ parō (“prepare”), ultimately from Proto-Indo-European *per- (“produce, procure, bring forward, bring forth”). Displaced Middle English scheden, from Old English scēadan (whence English shed).

entries.meaning: Apart from (the rest); not connected to or attached to (anything else).
examples: This chair can be disassembled into five separate pieces.
I try to keep my personal life separate from work.

entries.meaning: (usually in the plural) Anything that is sold by itself, especially articles of clothing such as blouses, skirts, jackets, and pants.
(bibliography) A printing of an article from a periodical as its own distinct publication and distributed independently, often with different page numbers.

verbs.description: separate (third-person singular simple present separates, present participle separating, simple past and past participle separated)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To divide (a thing) into separate parts.
examples: Separate the articles from the headings.
Synonyms: partition, split; see also Thesaurus:divide

entries.meaning: (transitive) To disunite from a group or mass; to disconnect.
examples: From the fine gold I separate the allay [alloy].

entries.meaning: (transitive) To cause (things or people) to be separate.
examples: If the kids get too noisy, separate them for a few minutes.

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To divide itself into separate pieces or substances.
examples: The sauce will separate if you don't keep stirring.
Synonyms: break down, come apart, disintegrate, fall apart

entries.meaning: (obsolete) To set apart; to select from among others, as for a special use or service.
examples: Separate me Barnabas and Saul for the work whereunto I have called them.
